TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua ti Muakai kati Muatjuku, a mare sikatsekeł.
izoa ti Moakai kati Moatjoko, a mare sikacekelj.
S.TRANSL: There were two cousins, Muakai and Muatjuku.

S.FORM: putsekeł ti Makułułu tjai Muakai; puałak tjai Sapulungan.
pocekelj ti Makoljoljo tjai Moakai; poaljak tjai Sapolongan.
S.TRANSL: Makułułu married Muakai, and their child was Sapulungan.

S.FORM: putsekeł ti Sapulungan tjai Muatjuku; puałak tjai Muakai.
pocekelj ti Sapolongan tjai Moatjoko; poaljak tjai Moakai.
S.TRANSL: (Another) Sapulungan married Muatjuku, and their child was Muakai.

S.FORM: łakua a kutji sakamaya, neka nu kinatsavatsavan; łakua matsaqu a qivu.
ljakoa a kotji sakamaya, neka no kinacavacavan; ljakoa macaqo a qivo.
S.TRANSL: But she was only a vagina, she had no body; but she could speak.
“Well, Muatjuku has had a girl.

S.FORM: ari tja łiłavaw; uła kisudju ti Sapulungan."
ari tja ljiljavaw; olja kisodjo ti Sapolongan."
S.TRANSL: Let’s go and visit them, so that Sapulungan can court her.”
They went to pay a visit.
“Where is your child?” they said when they arrived.
She was hidden.
“There’s none.
Our child didn’t live.”
The visitors went back.
Sapulungan grew up.

S.FORM: vaik a qemałup tua uri sikisudju.
vaik a qemaljop toa ori sikisodjo.
S.TRANSL: He went to hunt something as a courting present.
(His parents sent a message:) “We are coming to arrange a marriage.”

S.FORM: saka, "mangtjez; uri tja kudain sa tja ałak a namaitutsu?
saka, "mangtjez; ori tja kodain sa tja aljak a namaitoco?
S.TRANSL: So (her parents said:) “They are coming. What are we going to do about our child like this?
We’re ashamed of her.
Let’s hide her.”
They got a trunk and put her in that.

S.FORM: satjezen a pasa tsemtsemel itua łiv, sa vayvayin a itung anga.
satjezen a pasa cemcemel itoa ljiv, sa vayvayin a itong anga.
S.TRANSL: They sent it off to a cave in the woods, and hung clothes round it.
Sapulungan found the place.

S.FORM: "aku namaitutsu a imaza, a liaw a itung anga, qau neka nu tsautsau?"
"ako namaitoco a imaza, a liaw a itong anga, qao neka no caocao?"
S.TRANSL: “Why is it like this, with lots of clothes and nobody here?”

S.FORM: patsunan nimadju a sema taladj tua łiv.
paconan nimadjo a sema taladj toa ljiv.
S.TRANSL: He looked inside the cave;
and there was the chest.
Sapulungan opened the lid.

S.FORM: manu izua i taladj a tsinavu.
mano izoa i taladj a cinavo.
S.TRANSL: Inside there was something wrapped up.
“Don’t unwrap me. I’m ashamed.”
“Who are you?”
“I’m Muatjuku’s child.”
“Why are you here?”
“I was hidden by mother.
Mother and the others said: ‘We’re ashamed of what others will say.’”
Sapulungan took her and put her in his net-bag (rucksack).

S.FORM: "anema, qalian, sa su kinavits a sadjelung?"
"anema, qalian, sa so kinavic a sadjelong?"
S.TRANSL: “Friend, what’s that heavy thing on your back?”
“łakaraw flowers (for head decorations).”

S.FORM: vaik timadju a isangas qemalats, sa vaik a sema tjumaq.
vaik timadjo a isangas qemalac, sa vaik a sema tjomaq.
S.TRANSL: He went ahead with a hunter’s shout of success, and went home.

S.FORM: semukavits, sa alapen a pasa surur, saka taqed.
semokavic, sa alapen a pasa soror, saka taqed.
S.TRANSL: He took off his load, took it to the bed platform and went to sleep.

S.FORM: "tekelu tua vava, kanu tua kinsa," nu aya a kina, "saqetju aken," aya sakamaya timadju.
"tekelo toa vava, kano toa kinsa," no aya a kina, "saqetjo aken," aya sakamaya timadjo.
S.TRANSL: When his mother said: “Drink some beer, have some food,” he just said: “I’m ill”.

S.FORM: tapuluq katu lima inika keman tua kinsa.
tapoloq kato lima inika keman toa kinsa.
S.TRANSL: He didn’t eat for 15 days.

S.FORM: "Sapulungan, uzai a vavuy," aya qaliqali, "sa-u alapu."
"Sapolongan, ozai a vavoy," aya qaliqali, "sa-o alapo."
S.TRANSL: Some people said: “Sapulungan, there are some wild pigs; go and get them.”
Sapulungan went hunting.

S.FORM: parimasudj a kina tua qaqerengan nimadju; manu izua nuki anema.
parimasodj a kina toa qaqerengan nimadjo; mano izoa noki anema.
S.TRANSL: His mother tidied his bed; and there was something there.

S.FORM: "manu mavan a saqetjuan nua ku ałak," aya, sa veritsan a pasa tekutekuan.
"mano mavan a saqetjoan noa ko aljak," aya, sa verican a pasa tekotekoan.
S.TRANSL: “So that was my son’s illness,” she said, and threw it down below (to the rubbish heap).

S.FORM: mangtjez ti Sapulungan; "ainu a ku..?" aya.
mangtjez ti Sapolongan; "aino a ko..?" aya.
S.TRANSL: Sapulungan came back. “Where is my..?” he said.
“What do you mean?
Your flute?
Your mouth-organ?”
“That’s not what I mean.”

S.FORM: "mavan ka su maya a ku siniverits."
"mavan ka so maya a ko siniveric."
S.TRANSL: “Perhaps you mean what I threw away.”
“Where did you throw it, mother?”
“I threw it down below.”

S.FORM: qau vaik ti Sapulungan sema zua.
qao vaik ti Sapolongan sema zoa.
S.TRANSL: So Sapulungan went down there.

S.FORM: manu izua ti Muakai, a naqemiladj i tekutekuan.
mano izoa ti Moakai, a naqemiladj i tekotekoan.
S.TRANSL: And there was Muakai, sitting there down below (having turned into a human being (OA)).

S.FORM: alapen ni Sapulungan a temavikił, a pasa kałuvułuvung.
alapen ni Sapolongan a temavikilj, a pasa kaljovoljovong.
S.TRANSL: Sapulungan took her and embraced her, and took her to the resting platform.
“I’ll give her a kiss,” said his mother.
Then there was an earthquake.

S.FORM: malap a kina tua qata, sa pavayan tjai Muakai, sana kisangutj, sana pavay tua anemanemanga siniputsekeł tjaimadju, sa pavayan tua matjałałak ni Muakai.
malap a kina toa qata, sa pavayan tjai Moakai, sana kisangotj, sana pavay toa anemanemanga sinipocekelj tjaimadjo, sa pavayan toa matjaljaljak ni Moakai.
S.TRANSL: His mother took precious beads and gave them to Muakai, and kissed her, and gave all sorts of wedding gifts for her, and gave them to Muakai’s parents.

S.FORM: "ai, manu izainu anga a tja ałak?" aya tiamadju a maḍusa, sana vaik a sema zua łemiław tjai Muakai.
"ai, mano izaino anga a tja aljak?" aya tiamadjo a madrosa, sana vaik a sema zoa ljemiljaw tjai Moakai.
S.TRANSL: “Oh, so where has our child got to?” they said, and went there to visit Muakai.

S.FORM: puałak anga ti Muakai kati Sapulungan, saka malevanga tiamadju.
poaljak anga ti Moakai kati Sapolongan, saka malevanga tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: Muakai and Sapulungan had a child and were very happy.
The end.
